tr.td:
ASSESSMENT: A 69-year-old male with right-sided neck pain and right upper extremity symptoms.
PLAN: We will start with physical therapy with some gentle traction and anti-inflammatory modalities as well as range of motion.
Plan to follow up in two to three months to see if patient has made any improvement and if not we can consider referring him to Dr. Bhat for some targeted facet injections likely at C6-C7 and also possibly at C3-C4. At this point, the patient is not keen on going forward with injections or surgery. Ultimately, he may consider that pending the ultimate diagnostic workup and effect of physical therapy if they are able to improve his symptoms. Follow up in two or three months.

text.paragraph:
Note:
A 69-year-old male who presents today with right-sided neck pain and right upper extremity symptoms. He has been seen by different specialists in our practice for cubital tunnel syndrome bilaterally as well as right shoulder issues with arthritis and rotator cuff pathology. He still has some right-sided neck pain that travels down his right shoulder area and into his right arm. When he sleeps at night he feels pain also going down to his right forearm and hand. He has had injections into the right shoulder and has had evaluation and management of his right shoulder but he still has persistent pain around the right paracervical region. The pain limits him in terms of range of motion of his neck. He finds that is quite bothersome to him. He is diabetic with a history of some peripheral neuropathy. Non-smoker. Right-hand dominant. He has not had prior surgery or injections in his neck but he has had injections in his shoulder and he has had surgery on his low back.

tr.td: As noted in the HPI are otherwise negative.

A 69-year-old male who can stand and move comfortably. Range of motion of the neck is full with some mild stiffness particularly in rotation to the left and right. Motor exam of the right upper extremity is without notable deficit. Sensation without deficit in the right upper extremity. Some positive impingement signs on the right shoulder which are consistent with his underlying shoulder pathology.
RADIOGRAPHIC REVIEW: X-rays and MRI of the cervical spine reviewed demonstrating cervical spondylosis noted throughout the cervical spine and the MRI of the right neck there are multiple levels of notable stenosis centrally and foraminally. Centrally at C4-C5 there is a decent amount of stenosis although there is still space from the cord. At C6-C7 there is severe right-sided foraminal stenosis. At C4-C5 there is also some mild-to-moderate right-sided foraminal stenosis. At C3-C4 also some moderate right-sided stenosis.
